text: Following a major wildfire event in Los Angeles County (FIPS 06037), our model predicts significant workforce disruption across multiple sectors. Entertainment and media are expected to see a 12% employment decline peaking around month 2, with recovery taking approximately 7 months. Hospitality and restaurants face a 25% employment drop, recovering in 9 months. Retail is projected to lose 18% of jobs with a 6-month recovery. Meanwhile, demand sectors surge: Construction rises 180% above baseline peaking at month 4 as rebuilding begins. Healthcare demand increases 15% in the first 2 months due to emergency services needs. Insurance and financial services see a 45% demand surge, peaking around months 2-4 as claims processing accelerates.

After a major hurricane event in Miami-Dade County (FIPS 12086), workforce disruption follows a characteristic curve. Tourism and hospitality see the steepest drop at 40% employment loss, with a projected 12-month recovery given the region's economic dependence on visitors. Retail declines 22% before recovering in 7 months. Transportation and logistics see an initial 15% decline from evacuation, followed by a 200% surge as supply chain restoration begins. Construction demand surges 320% over baseline, peaking at month 5 and remaining elevated for 18-24 months. Insurance adjusters are in extremely high demand, with a 90% increase in job openings persisting for 12+ months. Emergency healthcare surges 30% immediately before normalizing at month 3.

For a major wildfire in San Diego County (FIPS 06073), our model anticipates moderate but widespread disruption. The tourism-dependent coastal economy means hospitality losses of 20% extending over 8 months. Military contractor and defense industries show resilience with less than 5% disruption. Retail declines 15% and recovers in 5 months. Construction demand surges 140% above baseline peaking at month 3. Environmental remediation (fire-specific) creates significant demand for months 3-12 as watershed and erosion management becomes critical in this region's unique geography.
